In this unit, we are exploring ratios and how they are used to solve problems. At the end of this investigation, ask yourself:

What do you understand about ratios and reasoning with ratios?

Student responses will vary. They may include any or all of the following, though students may choose more colloquial vocabulary than what appears here:

  • Comparison statements compare two quantities("for every," fraction statements, etc.).
  • Comparison statements can be additive or multiplicative.
  • Ratios are comparisons of two quantities. The ratio tells the multiplicative relationship between two quantities.
  • Ratios can be written with the actual numbers (raw numbers) or with an equivalent (scaled) relationship between the quantities.
  • Ratios can be written as part-to-part or part-to-whole comparisons.
  • Ratios with the same multiplicative relationship are equivalent ratios.
  • Proportional reasoning is using ratios to answer questions.
  • The order of the ratio statement does not matter as long as the quantities are labeled correctly.
  • Additive and multiplicative comparison statements are used for different purposes.
